org.easylibs.options

Interface Option<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the generic type of the option's value
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BeanOption, PropertyOption

    public interface Option<T>

    An application defined command line option. An option consists of an option name and an option value. The name is used to match an option with the command line arguments. Options may consume one or more arguments from the command line, which are typically then returned as option values after being mapped to java types.

    Option value types can be of any type as long as there is a mapping for the type. The most basic option doesn't take any additonal arguments and by default its value type is mapped to be boolean. While other options may take 1 or more arguments and can be mapped to privitive types, arrays, collections and even enums. To register new types or override existing ones use the method TypeRegistry.register(java.lang.Class<T>, org.easylibs.options.TypeMapper<T>).

    Option interface has several different implementations that simplify working with command line options. For example there are simple options, bean options, java properties options and others. When the option value is changed, the various implementations also sync the value with their implementation and underlying container. For example a bean option will also possibly set a class field value as the option's value is changed.

    Options are grouped using an Options group and are then passed to command line parser Args for parsing all the command line arguments. For convenience, the Args command line parser contains sevaral static methods that combine the steps neccessary to create an option and parse the command line, but for more control, those steps should be done separately.

    Examples

     Option<Boolean> option1 = Option.of("option1");
 Option<Integer> option2 = Option.of("option2", int.class);

    Here we are working with an enum option, where the command line argument will be converted (case insensitive) to the enum constant and set as the option's value. Further more we demonstrate that its easy to define arrays and collections of any type, in this example's case using our MyEnum generic type. 

     public enum MyEnum {A,B,C}
 Option<MyEnum> option3 = Option.of("option3", MyEnum.class);
 Option<MyEnum[]> option4 = Option.of("option4", MyEnum[].class);
 Option<Collection<MyEnum>> option5 = Option.of("option5", Collection.class, MyEnum.class);

    Lastly we can pass our options to a command line parser and if any options we defined appear on the comamnd line, their arguments will be set as option values. In our case that is boolean, int, MyEnum, array of MyEnum and a collection of the same type. 

     String[] argv = ...; // from the command line
 Args args = Args.of(argv, option1, option2, option3, option4, option5);
 args.getMatchedOptions.forEach(option -> System.out.println(option));

    Note: The Args parser raises an exception on any parsing errors which should be caught and handled.

    Note: Even though we define a new enum class, the parser, or more accurately the TypeRegistry creates an automatic mapping for us to map the command line string argument to our enum constant(s).

    Note: The default type mapper uses case insensitive comparison of the command line argument to enum constant names. To override that mapping and make it case sensitve for example, register a new mapper before the option is used by the parser such as TypeRegistry.register(MyEnum.class, MyEnum::valueOf).

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Name.
        Returns:
        the string

      • getValue

        T getValue()
        Gets the current value of the option. If the option is not matched the value will be set to its default value.
        Returns:
        the option value and can be the default value or even null

      • getOptionalValue

        default java.util.Optional<T> getOptionalValue()
        Gets the value only when the option is matched and the value is there.
        Returns:
        the optional value, this method never returns null

      • isMatched

        boolean isMatched()
        Checks if the option is matched on the command line
        Returns:
        true, if found on the command line, otherwise false

      • isUnmatched

        default boolean isUnmatched()
        The option was never matched with the command line
        Returns:
        true, if is unmatched

      • min

        int min()
        Minimum number of arguments required by this option
        Returns:
        the minimum count

      • max

        int max()
        Maximum number of arguments required by this option
        Returns:
        the maximum count

      • onMatch

        Option<T> onMatch(java.util.function.Consumer<T> action)
        When the option is matched on the command line, execute the supplied action on the option's value
        Parameters:
        action - the action to perform on a successful option match
        Returns:
        the current option for call chaining
